post_text: Today, we celebrate the last day of school, and we commemorate Juneteenth, an American holiday celebrated annually on June 19th. It commemorates June 19, 1865, when Union general Gordon Granger read federal orders in Galveston, Texas, that all previously enslaved people in Texas were free. This is celebrated in 46 states, including Massachusetts. The Museum of the National Center of Afro-American Artists, Inc. is leading local celebrations in Boston, and blackboston.com has shared events going on too!

Ahmaud Arbery. Breonna Taylor. George Floyd. The murders of these three black Americans are the most recent examples of institutional racism. Amy Cooper is the most recent example of the exploitation of white privilege. The fact that members of black and brown communities are dying at higher rates a result of COVID-19 speaks to ongoing systemic failures in our country.

APR is an institution that is grounded in equity and antiracism. We stand as allies working to dismantle institutional racism as well as both implicit and explicit bias.

A post here is not adequate to express emotions or to fully communicate allyship. It's a start to acknowledge the context and pain in our community.

We hear, see, and feel the pain that exists right now. We stand together with all community members as allies and partners in the work to confront racism in all its forms.

This morning, co-founders of We Grow Microgreens, Lisa Evans and Tim Smith, hosted a ribbon cutting ceremony for their new greenhouse farm--and it's just a five minute walk from APR! The We Grow Microgreens, LLC greenhouse will bring highly nutritious and delicious microgreens and edible flowers to Readville, Hyde Park, and Boston! They use organic and sustainable growing practices and there is even a growing pumpkin patch, which is fitting for this time of year.

Mayor Marty Walsh and City Councilors Tim McCarthy and Boston City Councilor Annissa Essaibi-George attended the event, as well as other representatives and neighbors.
Students from Boston Latin Academy, Epiphany School, and others, are founding farmers and work at the farm. We are thrilled to be so close to such an exciting, local, urban farm!
